comment: Hey guys, there’s been a ton of news the past week about a vulnerability in the WPA2 protocol that protects our Wi-Fi networks, and since we say that AES is secure in this video, we thought it would be helpful to explain how it all relates. In October of 2017, researchers released a viable hack against WPA2, known as KRACK Attack, which uses AES to ensure secure communication between computers and network routers. The problem isn't with AES, which is provably secure, but with the communication protocol between router and computer. In order to set up secure communication, the computer and router have to agree through what's called a "handshake".  If this handshake is interrupted in just the right way, an attacker can cause the handshake to fault to an insecure state and reveal critical information which makes the connection insecure. As is often the case with these situations, the problem is with an implementation, not the secure algorithm itself. Our friends over at Computerphile have a great video on the topic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mYtvjijATa4

Fantastic Ghosts, in addition to the ability to slow the playback down, and the ability to watch the video repeatedly, try to understand that "Crash Course" by definition, is not really intended as a singular source of information. Consider it more like Cliff's Notes. It's something that is best served as a supplemental source. At the same time, if you have sufficient backround knowledge, you can still potentially learn quite a lot from this alone. In this case, it really helps to have a strong grasp of mathematics and particularly discrete structures. Without that, then yeah, it's nearly impossible to teach cryptography, a field that took millenia to develop, and comprises an entire semester-long college course on it's own down to 12.5 minutes. Instead, just think of it as an introduction to the concepts that cryptography is forced to worry about. Speaking as someone with a Computer Science degree, and who took Cryptography, and who has spent years doing cryptographic work, I promise you, this information is presented with excellent accuracy and precision. This whole course has been overall _incredible_. I'm used to reading articles from outside sources on things that I actually know about and find at least one glaring flaw, and usually closer to about 2.5 glaring misunderstandings. On CC-CS, their fact-checking has been _excellent_. Mistakes and glaring omissions are nearly non-existent. Some topics, they've covered managed to be better than I experienced in entire hour-long lectures on the same topic.

hey carrie (or anyone else if you would like to help) ,  I wanted to understand that private key sharing( at 10:00) , so i thought of making myself a simple practical example out of it, but my calculations say your equation from 10:00 is not correct . can you please have a look?      So If i have to transmit character '"P' (ascii 80 )from Boy A to B:   >> I assumed x=2 would be private key of A and y=3 would be private key of B)  >> I assumed my public  key function as cipher(x,y)= (3^x % 7)^y Thus:     -  A would first Transfer cipher_a = 3^2%7 = 2 to B    -  B would first Transfer cipher_ a= 3^3%7 = 6 to A    >> I assumed my publically available encryptor function as  encrypted_text = cipher(B) ^x  + ascii(character)  - Thus, A would transfer the encrypted character 'P' to be as  e_t = (6)^2+80 = 106    >> I assumed my publically available decryptor function as   ascii(character) = encrypted_text - cipher(A) ^y  - Thus, B would recieve the value as val =  106-  (2)^3 = 97 , which is not equal to our original value of 80   Thus (B^y mod M)^x != (B^x mod M)^y != (B^xy mod M)   But rather (B^yx mod M^x) == (B^xy mod M^y) but != B^xy %M   Is this right?

An interesting addition:  The first version of Enigma, the one which had only 3 rotors has been cracked even before the beginning of WWII by 3 Polish mathematicians. Unfortunately their methods became obsolete the moment the 2 additional rotors have been added to the machine, making it again impossible do decipher Enigma until the Turing's breakthrough. (A commemorative memorial of the Polish input was placed in 2002 at Bletchley Park).

I think it would be a great idea to make a second video where you talk about vulnerabilities of cryptography! For example, Diffie-Hellman is only secure against passive attacks; however you can fool both sides into thinking that a secure connection is established by a man-in-the-middle attack. There are different ways to eliminate this problem. Also public keys need to be stored in a secure source. If an attacker is able to distribute his own public key, it will lead to problems.  There are many more examples, which could easily fill another video.  I loved this one, it was a great introduction, but I wish you would go into more detail, especially since it might give the impression that these algorithms have no flaws :)

The "Bomba" was a special-purpose machine designed about October 1938 by Polish Cipher Bureau cryptologist Marian Rejewski to break German Enigma-machine ciphers. Alan Turing used this machine to make his electro-mechanical device and named it "Bombe". So Marian Rejewski and not Turing broke the Enigma code! Please CrashCourse, stop spreading misinformation.
As a total n00b in programming or encryption for some reason I understood the Debbie Hellman explanation over the paint trading analogy. Thanks.

In practical modular exponantiation you don't calculate the B^n before taking mod m since this number would be stupidly big and probably wont fit into memory. Instead you divide it into a series of taking power 2.  If n = 2k is even, then B^n = (B^2)^k. If n = 2k+1 is odd, then B^n = B(B^2)^k.  If B^2 > m, let C = B^2 mod m, then and (B^2)^k mod m = (B^2 mod m)^k = C^k (Also B(B^2)^k mod m = B(B^2 mod m)^k = BC^k). It is quite easy  to code this if you want to give it a try.

Guys, at 0:35 you used the picture of the monument dedicated to the 3 Polish mathematicians who first broke the Enigma cipher in 1932, making it possible for Turing et al. at Bletchley Park to proceed. Yet you didn't breathe a word of their contribution, nor did you even credit the photo (here it is on Wikipedia, recognizable by the digit order at the top: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Polish_cryptologists_breaking_Enigma_ciphers_monument_01.JPG ). I can understand that the English speaking world may be unwilling to break their tongues on names such as Różycki, but the complete erasure of the Polish contribution in ANY account of the Enigma-breaking is more than a little unfair.

I love this course, and I'd like to add a little more information (due to the fact that CC cannot cover everything in just 15 minutes).  First, when Carrie Ann says that one-way functions are "easy to do in one direction, but hard to reverse", "easy" and "hard" refer to computational complexity, specifically polynomial time problems. This means that the time needed to apply a one-way function must be small (a polynomial in the length of the argument of the function), but the time needed to reverse the computation must be awfully big.  Second, the existence of one-way functions is an open problem in computer science. Modular exponentiation is a candidate for being a one-way function: indeed, computing the function is easy, even for huge numbers, but the reverse (the modular discrete logarithm) is believed to be difficult (but it has not been proved!).

The British tried to break the Enigma first, but failed and gave up, concluding that the Enigma is perfectly secure. The Polish managed to break the original Enigma, handing their results to the British right before Germany attacked Poland. Using the results from Poland, GB started to systematically decrypt German communication. If the British hadn't known that the original Enigma was breakable, they neither would've the infrastructure (& mathematician) nor the hope to break the subsequent versions. Also, all versions of the Enigma were based on the same principle, so they could reuse parts the Polish results and "only" had to break the additions the Germans made. So all in all, that the Polish broke the first Enigma was crucial for the British. That's not to say that the British mathematicians didn't do much, on the contrary, they had to come up with ways to break the way more secure later Enigma version, which certainly wasn't easy.

Hey guys, there’s been a ton of news the past week about a vulnerability in the WPA2 protocol that protects our Wi-Fi networks, and since we say that AES is secure in this video, we thought it would be helpful to explain how it all relates. In October of 2017, researchers released a viable hack against WPA2, known as KRACK Attack, which uses AES to ensure secure communication between computers and network routers. The problem isn't with AES, which is provably secure, but with the communication protocol between router and computer. In order to set up secure communication, the computer and router have to agree through what's called a "handshake".  If this handshake is interrupted in just the right way, an attacker can cause the handshake to fault to an insecure state and reveal critical information which makes the connection insecure. As is often the case with these situations, the problem is with an implementation, not the secure algorithm itself. Our friends over at Computerphile have a great video on the topic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mYtvjijATa4
Have a good day, fellow youtuber! :)

Very nearly, but not quite the same thing. Decipher just means to make it sensible while undoing the cypher means to reverse the cypher put on it. Attempting to decipher, without any understanding of the cypher, could wind up with a false positive, i.e. a message which appears sensible but which is actually not the correct message.

Actually, we already did a long time ago.^^ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_cryptography

Actually, the most devastating quantum attack (Shor) only breaks asymmetric encryption (RSA, DH key exchange). Grover can weaken AES, but that isn't nearly as bad (speedup by at most the square root).  Other algorithms, including some asymmetric ones, might not be affected at all. djb & Tanja Lange have a 32C3 talk https://youtu.be/-LlkJZJ5DMQ and a mostly readable 2017 paper, "Post-quantum cryptography".

You can slow the playback down, can't you? It's not too fast for me. But I have heard others mentioning changing the speed of playback of youtube videos in general.

Fantastic Ghosts, in addition to the ability to slow the playback down, and the ability to watch the video repeatedly, try to understand that "Crash Course" by definition, is not really intended as a singular source of information. Consider it more like Cliff's Notes. It's something that is best served as a supplemental source. At the same time, if you have sufficient backround knowledge, you can still potentially learn quite a lot from this alone. In this case, it really helps to have a strong grasp of mathematics and particularly discrete structures. Without that, then yeah, it's nearly impossible to teach cryptography, a field that took millenia to develop, and comprises an entire semester-long college course on it's own down to 12.5 minutes. Instead, just think of it as an introduction to the concepts that cryptography is forced to worry about. Speaking as someone with a Computer Science degree, and who took Cryptography, and who has spent years doing cryptographic work, I promise you, this information is presented with excellent accuracy and precision. This whole course has been overall _incredible_. I'm used to reading articles from outside sources on things that I actually know about and find at least one glaring flaw, and usually closer to about 2.5 glaring misunderstandings. On CC-CS, their fact-checking has been _excellent_. Mistakes and glaring omissions are nearly non-existent. Some topics, they've covered managed to be better than I experienced in entire hour-long lectures on the same topic.
